What exactly does the journal bit mean anyway?  Never really understood that.

it's a scratch place for the kernel to make note about important changes it is about to make, so that if it doesn't get to finish making those changes, it knows about it when it boots up again adn can either finish the changes, or undo them... so the change either gets all done, or not done at all

the net result is certain operations are slowed down a bit ( because more data has to be written to the disk, once to the journal, and once to the real location ) but if the system crashes, you don't end up with a damaged filesystem
Sounds like a worthwhile sacrifice to me.
